hints_html: First compute the Maclaurin series for the integrand.
hints_latex: First compute the Maclaurin series for the integrand.
hints_raw: First compute the Maclaurin series for the integrand.
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
Since the Maclaurin series for \(e^{y}\) is

\(\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{y^n}{n!},\)

the Maclaurin series for \(e^{-x^2}\) is

\(\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-x^2)^n}{n!} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{n!}= 1 - x^2 + \frac12 x^4 - \frac{1}{6} x^6 +\dots\)

Hence, the first few nonzero terms of the Maclaurin series for the integrand \(\frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}\) are

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{x}\left( \left(1 - x^2 + \frac12 x^4 - \frac{1}{6} x^6+\dots \right) - 1 \right) &= - x + \frac12 x^3 - \frac{1}{6} x^5+\dots.\end{aligned}\]

Anti-differentiating these, we obtain the first few nonzero terms of the indefinite integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}\, dx,\end{aligned}\]

\(C - \frac{x^2}{2} + \frac18 x^4 - \frac{1}{36} x^6+\dots\)
sols_latex:
Since the Maclaurin series for $e^{y}$ is

$\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{y^n}{n!},$

the Maclaurin series for $e^{-x^2}$ is

$\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-x^2)^n}{n!} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{n!}=  1 - x^2 + \frac12 x^4 - \frac{1}{6} x^6 +\dots$

Hence, the first few nonzero terms of the Maclaurin series for the
integrand $\frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}$ are

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{x}\left( \left(1 - x^2 + \frac12 x^4 - \frac{1}{6} x^6+\dots \right) - 1 \right) &= - x + \frac12 x^3 - \frac{1}{6} x^5+\dots.
\end{align*}

Anti-differentiating these, we obtain the first few nonzero terms of the
indefinite integral
\begin{align*}
\int \frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}\, dx,
\end{align*}

$C - \frac{x^2}{2} + \frac18 x^4 - \frac{1}{36} x^6+\dots$
sols_raw:
Since the Maclaurin series for <math> e^{y}</math> is

<math> \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{y^n}{n!},</math>

the Maclaurin series for <math> e^{-x^2} </math> is 

<math> \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-x^2)^n}{n!} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{n!}=  1 - x^2 + \frac12 x^4 - \frac{1}{6} x^6 +\dots
</math>

Hence, the first few nonzero terms of the Maclaurin series for the integrand <math> \frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x} </math> are 


<math>\begin{align} 
\frac{1}{x}\left( \left(1 - x^2 + \frac12 x^4 - \frac{1}{6} x^6+\dots \right) - 1 \right) &= - x + \frac12 x^3 - \frac{1}{6} x^5+\dots.
\end{align}</math>


Anti-differentiating these, we obtain the first few nonzero terms of the indefinite integral 
<math>\begin{align}\int \frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}\, dx,\end{align}</math>

<math>
C - \frac{x^2}{2} + \frac18 x^4 - \frac{1}{36} x^6+\dots
</math>
statement_html:
Give the first three nonzero terms of the Maclaurin series (power series in \(x\)) for
\(\int \frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}\, dx.\)
statement_latex:
Give the first three nonzero terms of the Maclaurin series (power series
in $x$) for\\$\int \frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}\, dx.$
statement_raw:
Give the first three nonzero terms of the Maclaurin series (power series in <math>x</math>) for<br />
<math>\int \frac{e^{-x^2}-1}{x}\, dx. </math>
